title: Orchard planted by non-Jew
vignette: An orchard was planted by a non-Jew but sold to a Jew before the first fruits matured. Does it qualify for bikkurim?

options.text: Qualifies; the current Jewish owner bears the obligation.
Disqualifies; original planting by a non-Jew taints the produce.

title: Orchard sold to non-Jew then reacquired
vignette: An orchard planted by a Jew was sold to a non-Jew, then later repurchased by a Jew before harvest. Does it qualify for bikkurim?

options.text: Qualifies; final Jewish ownership restores its status.
Disqualifies; interim non-Jewish ownership invalidates it.

title: Sharecropper’s bikkurim
vignette: A sharecropper cultivates land owned by another Jew. Who must bring the first fruits?

options.text: Sharecropper; he did the work and harvested the fruit.

title: Co-owned orchard by Jew and non-Jew
vignette: An orchard is jointly owned by a Jew and a non-Jew. Do its fruits qualify for bikkurim?

options.text: Qualifies; the Jewish owner’s share suffices.
Disqualifies; any non-Jewish stake disqualifies the produce.

title: Returnee’s recitation
vignette: An Israelite who lived abroad then returned brings bikkurim. Should he recite the standard “which You gave our ancestors” formula or a modified version?

options.text: Standard formula; join the collective heritage.
Modified version; clarify his personal return.

title: Convert’s confession
vignette: A convert stands among bikkurim presenters. Must he recite a unique confession acknowledging his personal redemption or the standard communal declaration?

options.text: Unique confession; reflect his individual journey.
Standard declaration; emphasize unity over individuality.

title: Impure presenter carrying basket
vignette: A man who is ritually impure from corpse-tumah brings his bikkurim basket to the Temple Mount. May he leave the basket there and depart without entering?

options.text: Yes; the basket may be placed even if he cannot ascend.
No; impurity invalidates the offering entirely.

title: Deaf-mute gesture blessings
vignette: A presenter is deaf-mute and cannot recite the blessing verbally. Should he use gestures to fulfill the obligation?

options.text: Yes; gestures suffice to convey the required intent.
No; verbal recitation is mandated by law.

title: Double designation of first fruits
vignette: A farmer ties a reed band around a fruit to mark it as first fruits. Must he also repeat that designation after picking it?

options.text: Yes; both field-marking and post-harvest declaration are required.
No; the initial in-field marking suffices.
